Subject: AS Level Business
Question: Analyse the disadvantages of performance related pay
User's Essay: Performance related pay is a financial motivator – a bonus paid on meeting specific performance targets. One disadvantage to a business using performance-related pay to motivate its employees is that it would entail the regular setting of targets against which each employee’s performance will be measured. This might cause inconveniences and inefficiencies as it eats into the senior manager’s schedule and list of responsibilities, burdening them with regular target setting and assessments whereas they could have spent their time planning new projects or product launches or marketing campaigns. In this case, the costs of performance-related pay exceed the motivational dividends that it promises. Another disadvantage is that this creates a scenario where discrimination and favoritism, both real and perceived, might arise to plague the workforce and employee-employer relations. If there is indeed favoritism, that is, the managers reward certain employees more than others regardless of their output level (which becomes a very convenient loophole for the managers in case the output isn’t that measurable), then it will distort incentives and breed resentment amongst the employees who are discriminated against. They won’t bother striving to improve the quality of their work as it no longer yields the promised rewards, scoring low instrumentality, according to Vroom’s Expectancy theory. Even if the discrimination is just perceived, the same distortion of incentives will follow, since instrumentality considers what the employees believe rather than what is actually the truth. This will result in the business achieving exactly the opposite of what it aimed to achieve and decrease motivation and productivity, leading to lower profits. Furthermore, performance-related pay can create stress among employees. Workers might feel pressured to work extra hard to earn more, potentially leading them to overwork themselves to increase their own pay. Overworked employees are often both demotivated and less efficient. The increased inefficiency can cause average costs to rise, thereby reducing the business's competitiveness. In some roles, such as that of a salesman, employees might push themselves too hard, which can lead to a poor customer experience as customers may feel pressured to make purchases they are not entirely comfortable with. This can make the implementation of performance-related pay counterproductive. Moreover, businesses might need to focus increasingly on improving worker morale to counteract the negative effects of performance-related pay, which reduces the time available for focusing on core activities. The need to address these morale issues can further strain the resources of the business.
Total Marks: 8

2. Detailed feedback and reasoning.

Effective communication and fair treatment by management can foster a positive environment where employees feel valued and are more likely to go the extra mile in their roles.

Only when the workers love their job will they be willing to work those extra hours which their job demands them to. A lack of morale in this scenario can lead to the business remaining closed in peak sales times – such as during a festival like Durga Puja – causing it to lose out on potential sales. Low morale and welfare also might lead to high labor turnover. This will increase the costs of the business as the new workers need to be trained again. For instance, the recruitment process by the HRM is an important aspect of the fast-food restaurant – the recruitment must not promote inequality. Greater diversity in the workforce, resulting from more merit-based recruitment, can infuse creativity into the workforce too. Good workforce planning can lead the HR managers to know the times when extra workers might be needed and hence prepare beforehand by hiring part-time workers.
